articles.title: About Me
articles.contents:
Who I Am
My name is Maxwell Lu, and I attend Newton North High School.
Email: maxtlu2005@gmail.com
About This Project
Evaluates over 300,000 samples of participants with or without heart
disease
Compares distinct risk factors and demographics through
straightforward bar charts
Project
Code
Created with the aid of Kane’s Free High School Data
Science Bootcamp

articles.title: Heart Disease: Risk Factors and Demographic
articles.description: Analyzing certain risk factors, ranging from smoking to obesity, that increase susceptibility to cardiovascular issues.
articles.contents:
Abstract
Heart disease is the leading cause of death for most ethnic groups in
the United States. The following data was pulled from Kamil Pytlak’s
Kaggle Dataset, which previously originated from a CDC telephone poll
responses regarding heart disease. From Pytlak’s dataset, Bar Chart data
was used to visualize the various factors contributing to heart disease
in an intuitive format. The data from this project shows that while
heart disease plagues much of the U.S. population today, humans can take
preventative measures. For example, it was found that both smoking and
diabetes contribute significantly to the number of people affected by
heart disease across several distinct races.
The chart below shows the exponentially proportional relationship
between age and that age’s percentage in the study’s total population
with heart disease.

Title of My Final Project


Home
Research
About
Source
☰


  
    
      
        
        
        
      
      
    
    
      
  Home


  Research


  About


  Source

      
  










heart2020 <- read_csv(file = "heart_2020_cleaned.csv")
## Rows: 319795 Columns: 18
## ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
## Delimiter: ","
## chr (14): HeartDisease, Smoking, AlcoholDrinking, Stroke, DiffWalking, Sex, ...
## dbl  (4): BMI, PhysicalHealth, MentalHealth, SleepTime
## 
## ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
## ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
introplot <- heart2020 |>
  group_by(AgeCategory)|>
  summarize(PercentageofHD = mean(HeartDisease == "Yes")) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = AgeCategory, y = PercentageofHD)) +
   geom_smooth(method = "loess", formula = y ~ x) +
  geom_col(fill = "maroon", color = "black") +
 scale_x_discrete(breaks = c("18-24", "30-34", "40-44", "50-54", "60-64", "70-74", "80 or older")) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format()) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank()) +
  labs(title = "The Age Distribution of People With Heart Disease",
       subtitle = "Risk for Heart Problems Increases With Age",
       x = "Age",
       y = "Percentage Heart Disease") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.text = element_text(face = "bold"), 
          axis.title.x = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.title.y = element_text(face = "bold"))
write_rds(introplot, "introplot.rds")

heart2020 <- read_csv(file = "heart_2020_cleaned.csv")
## Rows: 319795 Columns: 18
## ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
## Delimiter: ","
## chr (14): HeartDisease, Smoking, AlcoholDrinking, Stroke, DiffWalking, Sex, ...
## dbl  (4): BMI, PhysicalHealth, MentalHealth, SleepTime
## 
## ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
## ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
heart2020 |>
slice_sample(n = 1000)
## # A tibble: 1,000 × 18
##    HeartDis…¹   BMI Smoking Alcoh…² Stroke Physi…³ Menta…⁴ DiffW…⁵ Sex   AgeCa…⁶
##    <chr>      <dbl> <chr>   <chr>   <chr>    <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>   <chr> <chr>  
##  1 No          27.3 No      No      No           0      10 No      Male  30-34  
##  2 No          26.4 No      No      No          25      20 Yes     Fema… 70-74  
##  3 No          35.5 Yes     No      No           0       7 No      Fema… 30-34  
##  4 No          28.3 No      No      No           0       0 Yes     Fema… 80 or …
##  5 No          28.3 No      No      No           0       0 No      Fema… 60-64  
##  6 No          23.7 No      No      No           0       3 No      Male  18-24  
##  7 No          32.6 Yes     No      No          20      20 No      Fema… 30-34  
##  8 No          32.1 Yes     No      No           0       0 No      Fema… 50-54  
##  9 No          32.9 No      No      No           0       0 No      Male  40-44  
## 10 No          29.2 No      No      No           0       0 No      Male  30-34  
## # … with 990 more rows, 8 more variables: Race <chr>, Diabetic <chr>,
## #   PhysicalActivity <chr>, GenHealth <chr>, SleepTime <dbl>, Asthma <chr>,
## #   KidneyDisease <chr>, SkinCancer <chr>, and abbreviated variable names
## #   ¹​HeartDisease, ²​AlcoholDrinking, ³​PhysicalHealth, ⁴​MentalHealth,
## #   ⁵​DiffWalking, ⁶​AgeCategory
## # ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more rows, and `colnames()` to see all variable names
sample1000 <- heart2020 |>
  slice_sample(n = 1000)
healthplot <- sample1000 |>
  group_by(GenHealth, Sex) |>
  summarize(mean_BMI = mean(BMI), .groups = "drop") |>
  ggplot(aes(x = GenHealth, y = mean_BMI, fill = Sex)) +
  geom_col(position = "dodge", color = "black") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("cornflowerblue", "lightpink")) +
  scale_x_discrete(limits = c("Poor", "Fair", "Good", "Very good", "Excellent")) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "The Average Body Mass Index in Five Categories of Health",
       subtitle = "Higher BMIs tend to result in worsened health",
       x = "General Health",
       y = "Average Body Mass Index (BMI)",
       fill = "Gender") +
      theme(plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.text = element_text(face = "bold"), 
          axis.title.x = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.title.y = element_text(face = "bold"))
write_rds(healthplot, "healthplot.rds")

heart2020 <- read_csv(file = "heart_2020_cleaned.csv")
## Rows: 319795 Columns: 18
## ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
## Delimiter: ","
## chr (14): HeartDisease, Smoking, AlcoholDrinking, Stroke, DiffWalking, Sex, ...
## dbl  (4): BMI, PhysicalHealth, MentalHealth, SleepTime
## 
## ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
## ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
heart2020
## # A tibble: 319,795 × 18
##    HeartDis…¹   BMI Smoking Alcoh…² Stroke Physi…³ Menta…⁴ DiffW…⁵ Sex   AgeCa…⁶
##    <chr>      <dbl> <chr>   <chr>   <chr>    <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>   <chr> <chr>  
##  1 No          16.6 Yes     No      No           3      30 No      Fema… 55-59  
##  2 No          20.3 No      No      Yes          0       0 No      Fema… 80 or …
##  3 No          26.6 Yes     No      No          20      30 No      Male  65-69  
##  4 No          24.2 No      No      No           0       0 No      Fema… 75-79  
##  5 No          23.7 No      No      No          28       0 Yes     Fema… 40-44  
##  6 Yes         28.9 Yes     No      No           6       0 Yes     Fema… 75-79  
##  7 No          21.6 No      No      No          15       0 No      Fema… 70-74  
##  8 No          31.6 Yes     No      No           5       0 Yes     Fema… 80 or …
##  9 No          26.4 No      No      No           0       0 No      Fema… 80 or …
## 10 No          40.7 No      No      No           0       0 Yes     Male  65-69  
## # … with 319,785 more rows, 8 more variables: Race <chr>, Diabetic <chr>,
## #   PhysicalActivity <chr>, GenHealth <chr>, SleepTime <dbl>, Asthma <chr>,
## #   KidneyDisease <chr>, SkinCancer <chr>, and abbreviated variable names
## #   ¹​HeartDisease, ²​AlcoholDrinking, ³​PhysicalHealth, ⁴​MentalHealth,
## #   ⁵​DiffWalking, ⁶​AgeCategory
## # ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more rows, and `colnames()` to see all variable names
smokeplot <- heart2020 |>
  mutate(Smoker_categorized = if_else(Smoking == "Yes", "Smokes", "Does Not Smoke")) |>
  select(Race, Smoker_categorized, HeartDisease, Diabetic) |>
  group_by(Race, Smoker_categorized, Diabetic) |> 
  summarize(Percent_HD = mean(HeartDisease == "Yes"), .groups = "drop") |>
  ggplot(aes(x = Race, y = Percent_HD, fill = Diabetic)) +
  coord_flip() +
  geom_col(color = "black") +
  facet_wrap(~Smoker_categorized) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format()) +
  theme_light() +
   theme(panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank()) +
  labs(title = "Percent of Smoking and Non-Smoking \nIndividuals from Each Race With Heart Disease",
       subtitle = "Individuals with Diabetes are more susceptible to heart issues",
       y = "Percent with Heart Disease in Each Race",
       x = "Race") +
    theme(plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"), 
          plot.subtitle = element_text(face = "italic"),
          axis.text = element_text(face = "bold"), 
          axis.title.x = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.title.y = element_text(face = "bold"))
write_rds(smokeplot, "smokeplot.rds")

heart2020 <- read_csv(file = "heart_2020_cleaned.csv")
## Rows: 319795 Columns: 18
## ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
## Delimiter: ","
## chr (14): HeartDisease, Smoking, AlcoholDrinking, Stroke, DiffWalking, Sex, ...
## dbl  (4): BMI, PhysicalHealth, MentalHealth, SleepTime
## 
## ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
## ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
heart2020
## # A tibble: 319,795 × 18
##    HeartDis…¹   BMI Smoking Alcoh…² Stroke Physi…³ Menta…⁴ DiffW…⁵ Sex   AgeCa…⁶
##    <chr>      <dbl> <chr>   <chr>   <chr>    <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>   <chr> <chr>  
##  1 No          16.6 Yes     No      No           3      30 No      Fema… 55-59  
##  2 No          20.3 No      No      Yes          0       0 No      Fema… 80 or …
##  3 No          26.6 Yes     No      No          20      30 No      Male  65-69  
##  4 No          24.2 No      No      No           0       0 No      Fema… 75-79  
##  5 No          23.7 No      No      No          28       0 Yes     Fema… 40-44  
##  6 Yes         28.9 Yes     No      No           6       0 Yes     Fema… 75-79  
##  7 No          21.6 No      No      No          15       0 No      Fema… 70-74  
##  8 No          31.6 Yes     No      No           5       0 Yes     Fema… 80 or …
##  9 No          26.4 No      No      No           0       0 No      Fema… 80 or …
## 10 No          40.7 No      No      No           0       0 Yes     Male  65-69  
## # … with 319,785 more rows, 8 more variables: Race <chr>, Diabetic <chr>,
## #   PhysicalActivity <chr>, GenHealth <chr>, SleepTime <dbl>, Asthma <chr>,
## #   KidneyDisease <chr>, SkinCancer <chr>, and abbreviated variable names
## #   ¹​HeartDisease, ²​AlcoholDrinking, ³​PhysicalHealth, ⁴​MentalHealth,
## #   ⁵​DiffWalking, ⁶​AgeCategory
## # ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more rows, and `colnames()` to see all variable names
BMIplot <- heart2020 |>
  mutate(avg_BMI = mean(BMI)) |>
  mutate(BMI_categorized = if_else(BMI > 28.3254, TRUE, FALSE)) |>
  group_by(BMI_categorized, Race) |>
  summarize(Percent_HD = mean(HeartDisease == "Yes"), .groups = "drop") |>
  ggplot(aes(x = BMI_categorized, y = Percent_HD, fill = Race)) +
  geom_col(position = "dodge", color = "black") +
   theme(panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank()) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format()) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Weight and Heart Disease",
       subtitle = "The overweight in all races aside from American Indian/Alaskan Native experience \nan increase in heart disease",
       x = "Above Mean BMI",
       y = "Percentage Heart Disease") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.text = element_text(face = "bold"), 
          axis.title.x = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.title.y = element_text(face = "bold"))
write_rds(BMIplot, "BMIplot.rds")

articles.title: My Research
articles.description: Examining several graphs relating obesity, smoking, diabetes, gender, and race to heart disease.
articles.contents:
Poor
health is associated with higher body mass index measurements






Smoking
and diabetes lead to increased rates of heart disease across multiple
races

articles.title: Source
articles.description: All data pulled from cleaned 2020 CDC dataset.
articles.contents:
Kaggle dataset: “Personal Key Indicators of Heart Disease.” (Pytlak 2020)
For more information about this topic, visit Pytlak’s Personal
Heart Disease Predictor.



Pytlak, Kamil. 2020. “Personal Key Indicators of Heart
Disease.” Kaggle. https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/kamilpytlak/personal-key-indicators-of-heart-disease.
